CMake.FindExe FindExe Tries to find the specified CMake executable:
  • Locally in ./<tools|packages<cmake.portable>|<cmake>/bin
  • In the PATH environment variable.

 *To avoid unpredictable generator usage, it is recommended to define it.*
 Equivalent to the `-G <generator-name>` option.

title: TeamFoundation
content:
TeamFoundation Native support for Azure DevOps (previously VSTS) / Team Foundation Server specific APIs. The general documentation on how to use CI server integration can be found here. This module does not provide any special APIs please use FAKE APIs and they should integrate into this CI server. If some integration is not working as expected or you have features you would like to use directly please open an issue.

Secret Variables:
This CI server supports the concept of secret variables and uses the Vault to store them. In order to access secret variables you need to use one of the fake 5 tasks from vsts-fsharp.

Environment.BaseRef BaseRef Environment.CI CI Environment.HeadRef HeadRef Environment.Action Action Environment.Home Home Environment.Workflow Workflow Environment.Repository Repository Environment.Actor Actor Environment.EventName EventName Environment.Ref Ref Environment.EventPath EventPath Environment.Sha Sha Environment.Actions Actions Environment.RunId RunId Environment.RunNumber RunNumber Environment.Workspace Workspace

title: Environment.BaseRef
content:
Environment.BaseRef 
BaseRef 

 Only set for forked repositories. The branch of the base repository.

title: Environment.CI
content:
Environment.CI 
CI 

 Always set to true, if present.

title: Environment.HeadRef
content:
Environment.HeadRef 
HeadRef 

 Only set for forked repositories. The branch of the head repository.

title: Environment.Action
content:
Environment.Action 
Action 

 The unique identifier (id) of the action.

title: Environment.Home
content:
Environment.Home 
Home 

 The path to the GitHub home directory used to store user data.
 For example, /github/home.

title: Environment.Workflow
content:
Environment.Workflow 
Workflow 

 The name of the workflow.

title: Environment.Repository
content:
Environment.Repository 
Repository 

 The owner and repository name. For example, octocat/Hello-World.

title: Environment.Actor
content:
Environment.Actor 
Actor 

 The name of the person or app that initiated the workflow. For example, octocat.

title: Environment.EventName
content:
Environment.EventName 
EventName 

 The name of the webhook event that triggered the workflow.

title: Environment.Ref
content:
Environment.Ref 
Ref 

 The branch or tag ref that triggered the workflow.
 For example, refs/heads/feature-branch-1.
 If neither a branch or tag is available for the event type, the variable will not exist.

title: Environment.EventPath
content:
Environment.EventPath 
EventPath 

 The path of the file with the complete webhook event payload.
 For example, /github/workflow/event.json.

title: Environment.Sha
content:
Environment.Sha 
Sha 

 The commit SHA that triggered the workflow.
 For example, ffac537e6cbbf934b08745a378932722df287a53.

title: Environment.Actions
content:
Environment.Actions 
Actions 

 Always set to true when GitHub Actions is running the workflow.
 You can use this variable to differentiate when tests are being run locally or by GitHub Actions.

title: Environment.RunId
content:
Environment.RunId 
RunId 

 A unique number for each run within a repository.
 This number does not change if you re-run the workflow run.

title: Environment.RunNumber
content:
Environment.RunNumber 
RunNumber 

 A unique number for each run of a particular workflow in a repository.
 This number begins at 1 for the workflow's first run, and increments with each new run.
 This number does not change if you re-run the workflow run.

title: Environment.Workspace
content:
Environment.Workspace 
Workspace 

 The GitHub workspace directory path.
 The workspace directory contains a subdirectory with a copy of your repository if your workflow uses the actions/checkout action.
 If you don't use the actions/checkout action, the directory will be empty.
 For example, /home/runner/work/my-repo-name/my-repo-name.

title: Context
content:
Context 

 This module tracks the context of the build.
 <remarks>
 This allows us to run some modules without any context and change behavior depending on the context
 (For example <c>Fake.Process</c> kills all processes when the Fake Context exists, but it should not when used
 as library)
 </remarks>

title: CreateProcess
content:
CreateProcess Module for creating and modifying CreateProcess<'TRes> instances. You can manage:
  • The command (ie file to execute and arguments)
  • The working directory
  • The process environment
  • Stream redirection and pipes
  • Timeout for the process to exit
  • The result and the result transformations (map, mapResult)

More extensions can be found in the CreateProcess Extensions CreateProcess.fromCommand fromCommand CreateProcess.fromRawCommandLine fromRawCommandLine CreateProcess.fromRawCommand fromRawCommand CreateProcess.ofStartInfo ofStartInfo CreateProcess.interceptStream interceptStream CreateProcess.copyRedirectedProcessOutputsToStandardOutputs copyRedirectedProcessOutputsToStandardOutputs CreateProcess.withWorkingDirectory withWorkingDirectory CreateProcess.disableTraceCommand disableTraceCommand CreateProcess.withCommand withCommand CreateProcess.replaceFilePath replaceFilePath CreateProcess.mapFilePath mapFilePath CreateProcess.appendSimpleFuncs appendSimpleFuncs CreateProcess.addOnSetup addOnSetup CreateProcess.addOnFinally addOnFinally CreateProcess.addOnStarted addOnStarted CreateProcess.addOnStartedEx addOnStartedEx CreateProcess.withEnvironment withEnvironment CreateProcess.withEnvironmentMap withEnvironmentMap CreateProcess.getEnvironmentMap getEnvironmentMap CreateProcess.setEnvironmentVariable setEnvironmentVariable CreateProcess.withStandardOutput withStandardOutput CreateProcess.withStandardError withStandardError CreateProcess.withStandardInput withStandardInput CreateProcess.map map CreateProcess.mapResult mapResult CreateProcess.redirectOutput redirectOutput CreateProcess.redirectOutputIfNotRedirected redirectOutputIfNotRedirected CreateProcess.withOutputEvents withOutputEvents CreateProcess.withOutputEventsNotNull withOutputEventsNotNull CreateProcess.addOnExited addOnExited CreateProcess.ensureExitCodeWithMessage ensureExitCodeWithMessage CreateProcess.ensureExitCode ensureExitCode CreateProcess.warnOnExitCode warnOnExitCode CreateProcess.withTimeout withTimeout

content: CreateProcess.fromCommand fromCommand Create a simple CreateProcess<_> instance from the given command.

title: CreateProcess.fromRawCommandLine
content:
CreateProcess.fromRawCommandLine fromRawCommandLine Create a CreateProcess from the given file and arguments Using BlackFox.CommandLine
See BlackFox.CommandLine for details open BlackFox.CommandLine CmdLine.empty |> CmdLine.append "build" |> CmdLine.appendIf noRestore "--no-restore" |> CmdLine.appendPrefixIfSome "--framework" framework |> CmdLine.appendPrefixf "--configuration" "%A" configuration |> CmdLine.toString |> CreateProcess.fromRawCommandLine "dotnet.exe" |> Proc.run |> ignore

title: Proc
content: Proc Module to start or run processes, used in combination with the CreateProcess API. Proc.startRaw startRaw Proc.startRawSync startRawSync Proc.start start Proc.startAndAwait startAndAwait Proc.run run

title: Proc.startRaw
content:
Proc.startRaw startRaw Starts a process. The process has been started successfully after the returned task has been completed. After the task has been completed you retrieve two other tasks:
  • One Raw - Task to indicate when the process exited (and return the exit-code for example)
  • One Result - Task for the final result object.

Note: The Result task might finish while the Raw task is still running, this enables you to work with the result object before the process has exited. For example consider a long running process where you are only interested in the first couple of output lines

title: Proc.startRawSync
content: Proc.startRawSync startRawSync Similar to startRaw but waits until the process has been started.

title: Proc.start
content: Proc.start start Starts the given process and waits for the Result task. (see startRaw documentation). In most common scenarios the Result includes the Raw task or the exit-code one way or another.

title: Proc.startAndAwait
content: Proc.startAndAwait startAndAwait Convenience method when you immediately want to await the result of start, just note that when used incorrectly this might lead to race conditions (ie if you use StartAsTask and access reference cells in CreateProcess after that returns)

title: Proc.run
content: Proc.run run Like start but waits for the result synchronously.

 Tries to find the tool via Env-Var. If no path has the right tool we are trying the PATH system variable.
 Considers PATHEXT on Windows.

title: ProcessUtils.tryFindLocalTool
content: ProcessUtils.tryFindLocalTool tryFindLocalTool Find a local tool in the given envar the given directories, the current directory or PATH (in this order) Recommended usage tryFindLocalTool "TOOL" "tool" [ "." ]

title: ProcessUtils.findLocalTool
content: ProcessUtils.findLocalTool findLocalTool Like tryFindLocalTool but returns the tool string if nothing is found (will probably error later, but this function is OK to be used for fake default values.

title: Changelog
content:
Changelog Contains helpers which allow to parse Change log text files. These files have to be in a format as described on keepachangelog Format
# Changelog All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file. The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/), and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html). ## [Unreleased] ## [0.1.0] - 2020-03-17 First release ### Added - This release already has lots of features [0.1.0]: https://github.com/user/MyCoolNewLib.git/releases/tag/v0.1.0 Changelog.Change Change Changelog.ChangeText ChangeText Changelog.Changelog Changelog Changelog.ChangelogEntry ChangelogEntry Changelog.Unreleased Unreleased Changelog.parseVersions parseVersions Changelog.createWithCustomHeader createWithCustomHeader Changelog.create create Changelog.fromEntries fromEntries Changelog.parse parse Changelog.load load Changelog.save save Changelog.promoteUnreleased promoteUnreleased

title: ReleaseNotes
content:
ReleaseNotes Contains helpers which allow to parse Release Notes text files. Either "simple" or "complex" format is accepted.
Formats:
- Simple format 1.1.10 - Support for heterogeneous XML attributes. Make CsvFile re-entrant. 1.1.9 - Infer booleans for ints that only manifest 0 and 1.
- Complex format ### New in 1.1.10 (Released 2013/09/12) * Support for heterogeneous XML attributes. * Make CsvFile re-entrant. * Support for compressed HTTP responses. * Fix JSON conversion of 0 and 1 to booleans. ### New in 1.1.9 (Released 2013/07/21) * Infer booleans for ints that only manifest 0 and 1. * Support for partially overriding the Schema in CsvProvider. * PreferOptionals and SafeMode parameters for CsvProvider. ReleaseNotes.ReleaseNotes ReleaseNotes ReleaseNotes.parseAll parseAll ReleaseNotes.parse parse ReleaseNotes.load load

title: SemVerInfo
content: SemVerInfo Contains the version information. For parsing use SemVer.parse Note: If you use { version with Patch = myPath; Original = None } to overwrite some parts of this string make sure to overwrite Original to None in order to recalculate the version string. For overwriting the PreRelease part use: { Version with Original = None; PreRelease = PreRelease.TryParse "alpha.1" } SemVerInfo.CompareTo CompareTo SemVerInfo.Equals Equals SemVerInfo.Normalize Normalize SemVerInfo.NormalizeToShorter NormalizeToShorter SemVerInfo.AsString AsString SemVerInfo.Major Major SemVerInfo.Minor Minor SemVerInfo.Patch Patch SemVerInfo.PreRelease PreRelease SemVerInfo.Build Build SemVerInfo.BuildMetaData BuildMetaData SemVerInfo.Original Original

title: Target.initEnvironment
content: Target.initEnvironment initEnvironment Allows to initialize the environment before defining targets This function should be used at the start of your fake script see issues #2283 Alternatively, you can use Target.getArguments() instead

title: Target.getArguments
content: Target.getArguments getArguments Allows to retrieve the arguments passed into the current execution, when Target.run*withArguments overloads are used, see Targets with arguments This function should be used at the start of your fake script Alternatively, you can use Target.initEnvironment() instead, Note: This function usually returns Some [||], it will return None when No actual execution was requested (for example because of --list), you shouldn't execute any side effects when None is returned (you should never execute side effects but you can use this flag to check if needed)

(==>) 

 Defines a dependency - y is dependent on x

title: TargetOperators.(?=>)
content:
TargetOperators.(?=>) 
(?=>) 

 Defines a soft dependency. x must run before y, if it is present, but y does not require x to be run.

title: TargetOperators.(<=?)
content:
TargetOperators.(<=?) 
(<=?) 

 Defines a soft dependency. x must run before y, if it is present, but y does not require x to be run.

title: TargetOperators.(<=>)
content:
TargetOperators.(<=>) 
(<=>) 

 Defines that x and y are not dependent on each other but y is dependent on all dependencies of x.

title: TargetOperators.(=?>)
content:
TargetOperators.(=?>) 
(=?>) 

 Defines a conditional dependency - y is dependent on x if the condition is true

title: BuildParams.LruSize
content:
BuildParams.LruSize 
LruSize 

 Set the LRU cached model count (approximately the same as the count of input files). By default, it is 8192 for 64bit and 3072 for 32bit process. With LRU cache enabled, memory usage decreases and time consumed increases. If set to 0, Lru cache is disabled.

title: BuildParams.KeepFileLink
content:
BuildParams.KeepFileLink 
KeepFileLink 

 If set to true, docfx does not dereference (aka. copy) file to the output folder, instead, it saves a link_to_path property inside mainfiest.json to indicate the physical location of that file.

title: BuildParams.CleanupCacheHistory
content:

CleanupCacheHistory 

 If set to true, docfx create a new intermediate folder for cache files, historical cache data will be cleaned up.

content:
CliInstallOptions.Channel Channel Specifies the source channel for the installation. The possible values are:
  • Current - Most current release.
  • LTS - Long-Term Support channel (most current supported release).
  • Two-part version in X.Y format representing a specific release (for example, 2.0 or 1.0).
  • Branch name. For example, release/2.0.0, release/2.0.0-preview2, or master (for nightly releases).
The default value is LTS. For more information on .NET support channels, see the .NET Support Policy page. Use the CliChannel module, for example CliChannel.Current

title: Options.Create
content: Options.Create Create Create a default setup for executing the dotnet command line. This function tries to take current global.json into account and tries to find the correct installation. To overwrite this behavior set DotNetCliPath manually (for example to the first result of ProcessUtils.findFilesOnPath "dotnet")

title: TestOptions.Filter
content:
TestOptions.Filter 
Filter 

 Run tests that match the given expression. (<c>--filter</c>)
 Examples:
 <list type="number">
 <item>
 Run tests with priority set to 1: <c>--filter "Priority = 1"</c>
 </item>
 <item>
 Run a test with the specified full name:
 <c>--filter "FullyQualifiedName=Namespace.ClassName.MethodName"</c>
 </item>
 <item>
 Run tests that contain the specified name: <c>--filter "FullyQualifiedName~Namespace.Class"</c>
 </item>
 <item>
 More info on filtering support: https://aka.ms/vstest-filtering
 </item>
 </list>

title: TestOptions.RunSettingsArguments
content:

RunSettingsArguments 

 Arguments to pass run settings configurations through commandline. Arguments may be specified as
 name-value pair of the form <c>[name]=[value]</c> after <c>"-- "</c>. Note the space after <c>--</c>.

title: TestOptions.Blame
content:
TestOptions.Blame 
Blame 

 Runs the tests in blame mode. This option is helpful in isolating the problematic tests causing test
 host to crash. It creates an output file in the current directory as Sequence.xml that captures the
 order of tests execution before the crash.  (<c>--blame</c>)

title: MSBuildLogParameter.Append
content:
MSBuildLogParameter.Append 
Append 

 Determines whether the build log is appended to the log file or overwrites it. When you set the switch,
 the build log is appended to the log file. When the switch is not present, the contents of an existing
 log file are overwritten. If you include the append switch, no matter whether it is set to true or false,
 the log is appended. If you do not include the append switch, the log is overwritten.

title: Mage
content:
Mage Contains helper functions which allow FAKE to call the Manifest Generation and Editing Tool, in short MAGE. The intentional use is the creation of a clickonce application. Certificates
The MAGE tool wants to sign the manifest using a certificate. It should be clear, that this file is not under source control. On the other hand - you want to be able to run the compile batch on each developer machine. How can we achieve that? In the parameter structure, we use a CertFile property and a TmpCertFile property. Whenever the CertFile was not found, the manifest is signed with a temporary certificate. And the latter one can be shared in the source control. Mage.MageParams MageParams Mage.Processor Processor Mage.TrustLevel TrustLevel Mage.createApp createApp Mage.updateApp updateApp Mage.signManifest signManifest Mage.deployApp deployApp Mage.updateDeploy updateDeploy Mage.signDeploy signDeploy Mage.run run

Mage.run 
run 

 Executes a full run of MAGE commands: first, it creates a new manifest file. Then it signs the manifest,
 deploys the application and finally signs the deployment.

title: Params.CustomRuleset
content:
Params.CustomRuleset 
CustomRuleset 

 Rule set to be used for the analysis. It can be a file path to the rule set
 file or the file name of a built-in rule set. <c>+</c> enables all rules in the
 rule set; <c>-</c> disables all rules in the rule set; <c>=</c> sets rules to match the
 rule set and disables all rules that are not enabled in the rule set.
 Default empty.

title: Restore
content: Restore Contains tasks which allow to restore NuGet packages from a NuGet package feed like nuget.org using the nuget.exe restore command. There is also a tutorial about nuget package restore available. Restore.NugetRestoreVerbosity NugetRestoreVerbosity Restore.RestorePackageParams RestorePackageParams Restore.RestoreSinglePackageParams RestoreSinglePackageParams Restore.findNuget findNuget Restore.RestorePackageDefaults RestorePackageDefaults Restore.RestoreSinglePackageDefaults RestoreSinglePackageDefaults Restore.runNuGet runNuGet Restore.runNuGetTrial runNuGetTrial Restore.buildSources buildSources Restore.buildNuGetArgs buildNuGetArgs Restore.RestorePackageId RestorePackageId Restore.RestorePackage RestorePackage Restore.RestorePackages RestorePackages Restore.RestoreMSSolutionPackages RestoreMSSolutionPackages

title: Restore.findNuget
content:
Restore.findNuget findNuget Looks for NuGet.exe in
  • the specified defaultPath
  • a list of standard tool folders
  • any subfolder in the current directory
  • the PATH - returns the first path where NuGet.exe was found.

content: NUnit3Runtime The --framework option in running NUnit 3. There are three kinds - VXY, which means either .NET framework or Mono, NetXY (use .NET framework with given version) and MonoXY (Mono framework with given version). You can use Net or Mono to let NUnit select the version. You can pass any value using Other. content: NUnitDomainModel The /domain option controls of the creation of AppDomains for running tests. title: NUnitDomainModel.DefaultDomainModel

DefaultDomainModel 

 The default is to use multiple domains if multiple assemblies are listed on the command line. Otherwise a
 single domain is used.

title: NUnitDomainModel.NoDomainModel
content:
NUnitDomainModel.NoDomainModel 
NoDomainModel 

 No domain is created - the tests are run in the primary domain. This normally requires copying the NUnit
 assemblies into the same directory as your tests.

 A test domain is created - this is how NUnit worked prior to version 2.4

 A separate test domain is created for each assembly

content: NUnitParams The NUnit Console Parameters type. FAKE will use `NUnitDefaults` for values not provided. For reference, see: NUnit-Console Command Line Options NUnitParams.IncludeCategory IncludeCategory NUnitParams.ExcludeCategory ExcludeCategory NUnitParams.ToolPath ToolPath NUnitParams.ToolName ToolName NUnitParams.DontTestInNewThread DontTestInNewThread NUnitParams.StopOnError StopOnError NUnitParams.SkipNonTestAssemblies SkipNonTestAssemblies NUnitParams.OutputFile OutputFile NUnitParams.Out Out NUnitParams.ErrorOutputFile ErrorOutputFile NUnitParams.Framework Framework NUnitParams.ProcessModel ProcessModel NUnitParams.ShowLabels ShowLabels NUnitParams.WorkingDir WorkingDir NUnitParams.XsltTransformFile XsltTransformFile NUnitParams.TimeOut TimeOut NUnitParams.DisableShadowCopy DisableShadowCopy NUnitParams.Domain Domain NUnitParams.ErrorLevel ErrorLevel NUnitParams.Fixture Fixture

title: NUnitParams.IncludeCategory
content: NUnitParams.IncludeCategory IncludeCategory The Categories to be included in a test run. Multiple categories may be specified on either option, by using commas to separate them.

title: NUnitParams.ExcludeCategory
content: NUnitParams.ExcludeCategory ExcludeCategory The Categories to be excluded in a test run. Multiple categories may be specified on either option, by using commas to separate them.

content: File.tryGetVersion tryGetVersion Tries to get the version of a file. Throws `FileNotFoundException` if the file doesn't exist. title: Wix.bulkComponentTreeCreation
content: Wix.bulkComponentTreeCreation bulkComponentTreeCreation Creates a WiX directory and component hierarchy from the given DirectoryInfo The function will create one component for each file best practice and set the GUID to "*", which will make WiX produce consistent Component Guids if the Component's target path doesn't change. This is vital for major upgrades, since windows installer needs a consistent component guid for tracking each of them. You can use the getComponentRefs function for getting all created component refs and adding them to features. You can use attachServiceControlToComponents or attachServiceInstallToComponents to attach ServiceControl or ServiceInstall to the directory component hierarchy

title: Wix.bulkComponentCreation
content: Wix.bulkComponentCreation bulkComponentCreation Creates WiX component with directories and files from the given DirectoryInfo The function will create one component for each file best practice and set the GUID to "*", which will make WiX produce consistent Component Guids if the Component's target path doesn't change. This is vital for major upgrades, since windows installer needs a consistent component guid for tracking each of them. You can use the getComponentIdsFromWiXString function for getting all created component refs and adding them to features.

title: Wix.bulkComponentCreationAsSubDir
content: Wix.bulkComponentCreationAsSubDir bulkComponentCreationAsSubDir Creates WiX component with directories and files from the given DirectoryInfo The function will create one component for each file best practice and set the GUID to "*", which will make WiX produce consistent Component Guids if the Component's target path doesn't change. This is vital for major upgrades, since windows installer needs a consistent component guid for tracking each of them. The components are embedded into the passed in root directory.

title: Wix.getWixDirTag
content: Wix.getWixDirTag getWixDirTag Creates recursive WiX directory and file tags from the given DirectoryInfo The function will create one component for each file best practice and set the GUID to "*", which will make WiX produce consistent Component Guids if the Component's target path doesn't change. This is vital for major upgrades, since windows installer needs a consistent component guid for tracking each of them. You can use the getComponentIdsFromWiXString function for getting all created component refs and adding them to features.

title: CustomAction.Id
content:
CustomAction.Id 
Id 

	The identifier of the custom action.

title: CustomAction.FileKey
content:
CustomAction.FileKey 
FileKey 

 This attribute specifies a reference to a File element with matching Id attribute that will execute the custom action code
 in the file after the file is installed. This attribute is typically used with the ExeCommand attribute to specify
 a type 18 custom action that runs an installed executable, with the DllEntry attribute to specify an installed custom action
 DLL to use for a type 17 custom action, or with the VBScriptCall or JScriptCall attributes to specify a type 21 or 22 custom action.

title: CustomAction.Execute
content:
CustomAction.Execute 
Execute 

 This attribute indicates the scheduling of the custom action.

title: CustomAction.Impersonate
content:
CustomAction.Impersonate 
Impersonate 

 This attribute specifies whether the Windows Installer, which executes as LocalSystem, should impersonate the user context of
 the installing user when executing this custom action. Typically the value should be 'yes', except when the custom action needs
 elevated privileges to apply changes to the machine.

title: CustomAction.ExeCommand
content:
CustomAction.ExeCommand 
ExeCommand 

 This attribute specifies the command line parameters to supply to an externally run executable.
 This attribute is typically used with the BinaryKey attribute for a type 2 custom action, the FileKey attribute for a type 18
 custom action, the Property attribute for a type 50 custom action, or the Directory attribute for a type 34 custom action that
 specify the executable to run.

title: CustomAction.Return
content:
CustomAction.Return 
Return 

 Set this attribute to set the return behavior of the custom action.

title: CustomActionExecute
content:
CustomActionExecute 

 Used in CustomAction for determing when to run the custom action
 
CustomActionExecute.Commit 
Commit 
CustomActionExecute.Deferred 
Deferred 
CustomActionExecute.FirstSequence 
FirstSequence 
CustomActionExecute.Immediate 
Immediate 
CustomActionExecute.OncePerProcess 
OncePerProcess 
CustomActionExecute.Rollback 
Rollback 
CustomActionExecute.SecondSequence 
SecondSequence

title: CustomActionExecute.Commit
content:
CustomActionExecute.Commit 
Commit 

 Indicates that the custom action will run after successful completion of the installation script
 (at the end of the installation).

title: CustomActionExecute.Deferred
content:
CustomActionExecute.Deferred 
Deferred 

 Indicates that the custom action runs in-script (possibly with elevated privileges).

title: CustomActionExecute.FirstSequence
content:
CustomActionExecute.FirstSequence 
FirstSequence 

 Indicates that the custom action will only run in the first sequence that runs it.

title: CustomActionExecute.Immediate
content:
CustomActionExecute.Immediate 
Immediate 

 Indicates that the custom action will run during normal processing time with user privileges. This is the default.

title: CustomActionExecute.OncePerProcess
content:
CustomActionExecute.OncePerProcess 
OncePerProcess 

 Indicates that the custom action will only run in the first sequence that runs it in the same process.

title: CustomActionExecute.Rollback
content:
CustomActionExecute.Rollback 
Rollback 

 Indicates that a custom action will run in the rollback sequence when a failure occurs during installation,
 usually to undo changes made by a deferred custom action.

title: CustomActionExecute.SecondSequence
content:
CustomActionExecute.SecondSequence 
SecondSequence 

 Indicates that a custom action should be run a second time if it was previously run in an earlier sequence.

title: CustomActionReturn.AsyncNoWait
content:
CustomActionReturn.AsyncNoWait 
AsyncNoWait 

 Indicates that the custom action will run asynchronously and execution may continue after the installer terminates.

title: CustomActionReturn.AsyncWait
content:
CustomActionReturn.AsyncWait 
AsyncWait 

 Indicates that the custom action will run asynchronously but the installer will wait for the return code at sequence end.

title: CustomActionReturn.Check
content:
CustomActionReturn.Check 
Check 

 Indicates that the custom action will run synchronously and the return code will be checked for success. This is the default.

title: CustomActionReturn.Ignore
content:
CustomActionReturn.Ignore 
Ignore 

 Indicates that the custom action will run synchronously and the return code will not be checked.

title: MajorUpgrade
content:
MajorUpgrade 

 Parameters for WiX Major Upgrade
 
MajorUpgrade.Schedule 
Schedule 
MajorUpgrade.AllowDowngrades 
AllowDowngrades 
MajorUpgrade.DowngradeErrorMessage 
DowngradeErrorMessage

title: MajorUpgrade.Schedule
content:
MajorUpgrade.Schedule 
Schedule 

 Determines the scheduling of the RemoveExistingProducts standard action, which is when the installed product is removed. The default is "afterInstallValidate" which removes the
 installed product entirely before installing the upgrade product. It's slowest but gives the most flexibility in changing components and features in the upgrade product.

title: MajorUpgrade.AllowDowngrades
content:
MajorUpgrade.AllowDowngrades 
AllowDowngrades 

 When set to no (the default), products with lower version numbers are blocked from installing when a product with a higher version is installed; the DowngradeErrorMessage
 attribute must also be specified. When set to yes, any version can be installed over any other version.

title: MajorUpgrade.DowngradeErrorMessage
content:
MajorUpgrade.DowngradeErrorMessage 
DowngradeErrorMessage 

 The message displayed if users try to install a product with a lower version number when a product with a higher version is installed. Used only when AllowDowngrades is no (the default).

title: MajorUpgradeSchedule
content:
MajorUpgradeSchedule 

 Used for determining when to run RemoveExistingProducts on major upgrade
 
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallValidate 
AfterInstallValidate 
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallInitialize 
AfterInstallInitialize 
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallExecute 
AfterInstallExecute 
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallExecuteAgain 
AfterInstallExecuteAgain 
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallFinalize 
AfterInstallFinalize

title: MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallValidate
content:
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallValidate 
AfterInstallValidate 

 (Default) Schedules RemoveExistingProducts after the InstallValidate standard action. This scheduling removes the installed product entirely before installing the upgrade product.
 It's slowest but gives the most flexibility in changing components and features in the upgrade product. Note that if the installation of the upgrade product fails,
 the machine will have neither version installed.

title: MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallInitialize
content:
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallInitialize 
AfterInstallInitialize 

 Schedules RemoveExistingProducts after the InstallInitialize standard action. This is similar to the afterInstallValidate scheduling, but if the installation of the upgrade product fails,
 Windows Installer also rolls back the removal of the installed product -- in other words, reinstall it.

title: MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallExecute
content:
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallExecute 
AfterInstallExecute 

 Schedules RemoveExistingProducts between the InstallExecute and InstallFinalize standard actions. This scheduling installs the upgrade product "on top of" the installed product then lets
 RemoveExistingProducts uninstall any components that don't also exist in the upgrade product. Note that this scheduling requires strict adherence to the component rules because it relies
 on component reference counts to be accurate during installation of the upgrade product and removal of the installed product. For more information, see Bob Arnson's blog post
 "Paying for Upgrades" for details. If installation of the upgrade product fails, Windows Installer also rolls back the removal of the installed product -- in other words, reinstalls it.

title: MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallExecuteAgain
content:
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallExecuteAgain 
AfterInstallExecuteAgain 

 Schedules RemoveExistingProducts between the InstallExecuteAgain and InstallFinalize standard actions.
 This is identical to the afterInstallExecute scheduling but after the InstallExecuteAgain standard action instead of InstallExecute.

title: MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallFinalize
content:
MajorUpgradeSchedule.AfterInstallFinalize 
AfterInstallFinalize 

 Schedules RemoveExistingProducts after the InstallFinalize standard action. This is similar to the afterInstallExecute and afterInstallExecuteAgain schedulings but takes place outside
 the installation transaction so if installation of the upgrade product fails, Windows Installer does not roll back the removal of the installed product,
 so the machine will have both versions installed.

title: RegistryKey.ForceCreateOnInstall
content:
RegistryKey.ForceCreateOnInstall 
ForceCreateOnInstall 

 Set this attribute to 'yes' to create an empty key, if absent, when the parent component is installed
 This value is needed only to create an empty key with no subkeys or values.
 Windows Installer creates keys as needed to store subkeys and values. The default is "no"

title: RegistryKey.ForceDeleteOnUninstall
content:
RegistryKey.ForceDeleteOnUninstall 
ForceDeleteOnUninstall 

 Set this attribute to 'yes' to remove the key with all its values and subkeys when the parent component is uninstalled
 Note that this value is useful only if your program creates additional values or subkeys under this key and you want an uninstall to remove them
 MSI already removes all values and subkeys that it creates, so this option just adds additional overhead to uninstall. The default is "no"

 Specifies the upper boundary of the range of product versions detected by FindRelatedProducts.

title: UpgradeVersion.Property
content:
UpgradeVersion.Property 
Property 

 When the FindRelatedProducts action detects a related product installed on the system, it appends the product code to the property specified in this field.
 Windows Installer documentation for the Upgrade table states that the property specified in this field must be a public property and must be added to the
 SecureCustomProperties property. WiX automatically appends the property specified in this field to the SecureCustomProperties property when creating an MSI.
 Each UpgradeVersion must have a unique Property value. After the FindRelatedProducts action is run, the value of this property is a list of product codes,
 separated by semicolons (;), detected on the system.

title: UpgradeVersion.IncludeMinimum
content:
UpgradeVersion.IncludeMinimum 
IncludeMinimum 

 Set to "no" to make the range of versions detected exclude the value specified in Minimum. This attribute is "yes" by default.

title: UpgradeVersion.IncludeMaximum
content:
UpgradeVersion.IncludeMaximum 
IncludeMaximum 

 Set to "yes" to make the range of versions detected include the value specified in Maximum.

title: Squirrel
content: Squirrel Contains types and utility functions related to creating Squirrel installer. Squirrel.ReleasifyParams ReleasifyParams Squirrel.releasify releasify

title: Squirrel.releasify
content:
Squirrel.releasify releasify Creates a Squirrel installer for given NuGet package. Will fail if Squirrel terminates with non-zero exit code.

Defaults for setParams:
  • ReleaseDir - ""
  • WorkingDir - None
  • BootstrapperExe - None
  • LoadingGif - None
  • SetupIcon - None
  • NoDelta - false
  • NoMsi - false
  • MsiWin64 - false
  • ToolPath - The squirrel.exe path if it exists in a subdirectory of the current directory.
  • TimeOut - 0 minutes
  • SignExecutable - None
  • SigningKeyFile - None
  • SigningSecret - None
  • FrameworkVersion - None
  • AdditionalArguments - None A string with additional arguments that will be added to the command line

content: ReleasifyParams The Squirrel Console Parameters type. For reference, see: Squirrel Command Line Options ReleasifyParams.ReleaseDir ReleaseDir ReleasifyParams.WorkingDir WorkingDir ReleasifyParams.BootstrapperExe BootstrapperExe ReleasifyParams.LoadingGif LoadingGif ReleasifyParams.SetupIcon SetupIcon ReleasifyParams.NoDelta NoDelta ReleasifyParams.NoMsi NoMsi ReleasifyParams.MsiWin64 MsiWin64 ReleasifyParams.ToolPath ToolPath ReleasifyParams.TimeOut TimeOut ReleasifyParams.SignExecutable SignExecutable ReleasifyParams.SigningKeyFile SigningKeyFile ReleasifyParams.SigningSecret SigningSecret ReleasifyParams.FrameworkVersion FrameworkVersion ReleasifyParams.AdditionalArguments AdditionalArguments

title: FTP
content: FTP Contains helpers which allow to upload a whole folder/specific file into a FTP Server. Uses Passive Mode FTP and handles all files as binary (and not ASCII). Assumes direct network connectivity to destination FTP server (not via a proxy). Does not support FTPS and SFTP. content: SignTool The SignTool tool is a command-line tool that digitally signs files, verifies signatures in files, or time stamps files. Documentation & samples SignTool.CertificateFromFile CertificateFromFile SignTool.CertificateFromStore CertificateFromStore SignTool.DigestAlgorithm DigestAlgorithm SignTool.SignCertificate SignCertificate SignTool.SignOptions SignOptions SignTool.TimeStampOption TimeStampOption SignTool.TimeStampOptions TimeStampOptions SignTool.Verbosity Verbosity SignTool.VerifyOptions VerifyOptions SignTool.sign sign SignTool.signWithTimeStamp signWithTimeStamp SignTool.timeStamp timeStamp SignTool.verify verify

 The SignTool verify command determines whether the signing certificate was issued by a trusted authority,
 whether the signing certificate has been revoked, and, optionally, whether the signing certificate is
 valid for a specific policy.

CertificateFromStore.AutomaticallySelectCertificate 
AutomaticallySelectCertificate 

 Selects the best signing certificate automatically. If this option is not present, SignTool expects
 to find only one valid signing certificate. (signtool option: /a)

title: CertificateFromStore.IssuerName
content:
CertificateFromStore.IssuerName 
IssuerName 

 Specifies the name of the issuer of the signing certificate. This value can be a substring of the
 entire issuer name. (signtool option: /i IssuerName)

title: CertificateFromStore.SubjectName
content:
CertificateFromStore.SubjectName 
SubjectName 

 Specifies the name of the subject of the signing certificate. This value can be a substring of the
 entire subject name. (signtool option: /n SubjectName)

title: CertificateFromStore.RootSubjectName
content:
CertificateFromStore.RootSubjectName 
RootSubjectName 

 Specifies the name of the subject of the root certificate that the signing certificate must chain to.
 This value can be a substring of the entire subject name of the root certificate. (signtool option:
 /r RootSubjectName)

title: CertificateFromStore.StoreName
content:
CertificateFromStore.StoreName 
StoreName 

 Specifies the store to open when searching for the certificate. If this option is not specified,
 the My store is opened. If the store does not exist, signtool will wail with a "File not found" error.
 (signtool option: /s StoreName)

title: CertificateFromStore.Hash
content:
CertificateFromStore.Hash 
Hash 

 Specifies the SHA1 hash of the signing certificate. When viewing a certificate, this is the value of
 the Thumbprint field. (signtool option: /sha1 Hash)

title: CertificateFromStore.UseComputerStore
content:
CertificateFromStore.UseComputerStore 
UseComputerStore 

 Specifies that a computer store, instead of a user store, be used. Accessing the computer store
 requires admin rights. If the process does not have admin rights, no certificates will be found.
 (signtool option: /sm)

title: VerifyOptions.AllMethods
content:
VerifyOptions.AllMethods 
AllMethods 

 Specifies that all methods can be used to verify the file. First, the catalog databases are
 searched to determine whether the file is signed in a catalog. If the file is not signed in any
 catalog, SignTool attempts to verify the file's embedded signature. This option is recommended
 when verifying files that may or may not be signed in a catalog. Examples of files that may or
 may not be signed include Windows files or drivers. (signtool option: /a)

title: VerifyOptions.AllSignatures
content:
VerifyOptions.AllSignatures 
AllSignatures 

 Verifies all signatures in a file with multiple signatures. (signtool option: /all)

title: VerifyOptions.PrintDescription
content:
VerifyOptions.PrintDescription 
PrintDescription 

 Print the description and description URL. (signtool option: /d)

content:
VerifyOptions.VerifyIndex 
VerifyIndex

title: VerifyOptions.UseX64KernelModeDriverSigningPolicy
content:
VerifyOptions.UseX64KernelModeDriverSigningPolicy 
UseX64KernelModeDriverSigningPolicy 

 Performs the verification by using the x64 kernel-mode driver signing policy. (signtool option: /kp)

title: VerifyOptions.UseMultipleVerificationSemantics
content:
VerifyOptions.UseMultipleVerificationSemantics 
UseMultipleVerificationSemantics 

 Uses multiple verification semantics. This is the default behavior of a WinVerifyTrust call.
 (signtool option: /ms)

title: VerifyOptions.VerifyByOperatingSystemVersion
content:
VerifyOptions.VerifyByOperatingSystemVersion 
VerifyByOperatingSystemVersion 

 Verifies the file by operating system version. The version parameter is of the form:
 PlatformID**:VerMajor.VerMinor.**BuildNumber. The use of the /o switch is recommended.
 If /o is not specified SignTool may return unexpected results. For example, if you do not include
 the /o switch, then system catalogs that validate correctly on an older OS may not validate
 correctly on a newer OS. (signtool option: /o Version)

title: VerifyOptions.UseDefaultAuthenticationVerificationPolicy
content:
VerifyOptions.UseDefaultAuthenticationVerificationPolicy 
UseDefaultAuthenticationVerificationPolicy 

 Specifies that the Default Authentication Verification Policy is used. If the /pa option is not
 specified, SignTool uses the Windows Driver Verification Policy. This option cannot be used with
 the catdb options. (signtool option: /pa)

title: VerifyOptions.RootSubjectName

VerifyOptions.RootSubjectName 
RootSubjectName 

 Specifies the name of the subject of the root certificate that the signing certificate must chain to.
 This value can be a substring of the entire subject name of the root certificate.
 (signtool option: /r RootSubjectName)

WarnIfNotTimeStamped

title: Reset.soft
content:
Reset.soft 
soft 

 Performs a git reset "soft".
 Does not touch the index file nor the working tree at all.

title: Reset.mixed
content:
Reset.mixed 
mixed 

 Performs a git reset "mixed".
 Resets the index but not the working tree and reports what has not been updated.

title: Reset.hard
content: Reset.hard hard Performs a git reset "hard". Resets the index and working tree. Any changes to tracked files in the working tree since <commit> are discarded.

title: Reset.ResetSoft
content:
Reset.ResetSoft 
ResetSoft 

 Performs a git reset "soft" to the current HEAD.
 Does not touch the index file nor the working tree at all.

title: Reset.ResetMixed
content:
Reset.ResetMixed 
ResetMixed 

 Performs a git reset "mixed" to the current HEAD.
 Resets the index but not the working tree and reports what has not been updated.

title: Reset.ResetHard
content: Reset.ResetHard ResetHard Performs a git reset "hard" to the current HEAD. Resets the index and working tree. Any changes to tracked files in the working tree since <commit> are discarded.
